posts.author: Thell
posts.content:
Hello all, I know I've not posted before but I've been lurking for a little while licking up the build tips, but I've got a question of my own for once.

Arelith, a level 30 RP server with mostly Vanilla mechanics (aside from one or two spell tweaks and a rule where one must take 3 consecutive levels in a class nor can one change alignment and remain an alignment restricted class) just came out with a new twist on Sorcerers and Bards last night, although the formers been around a while longer.

This new twist is called weave mastery; a Spontaneous Caster can cast his spells an infinete number of times per day, however there is a cooldown period between casts. For every spell level above one, a caster must wait Spell level X 6 seconds to cast any of his spells again. So After casting Darkness, my Sorcerer would have to wait six RL seconds to cast again, albit he can Melee attack and use Wands/scrolls in the meantime.

Quickened Spells are not subject to cooldown, so provided they were cast using the feat a level 17 Sorc can use level 0-4 spells as often as he likes. Auto-Quicken feats remove six seconds from the countdown of spells not cast using quicken spell. 
Since Bards cannot achive high level spells and take much advantage out of Quicken, they get -50% Arcane Spell Failure and can use Raise Dead an Infinete number of times (without countdown), but they also lose Bard and Curse Song.

So...What do you think fellas, is this useable or just trash? Honestly, the Sorc version looks horrible to me (Casting Wail leaves me powerless for 48 seconds? Yeiks!). The Bard version seems somewhat better, might even be decent in a Bard/BG/PM mix build but still weaker than the non-Weave counterpart in anything other than long rest-restricted dungeon runs.

Thanks for any feedback

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Honest opinion? All of them are trash. All of them. That is the problem with some heavy-rp worlds. They try to balance so many things that were not meant to be balanced this way. Sorcerers will wait 54 seconds to cast another 9th lvl spell? Then the spontaneous casting is rendered useless. And there is no way the superb 16th lvl Bard song/ Curse song is worth so little. If nothing else the changes to Bards are even worse!

posts.author: JimDandy
posts.content:
Bards with Raise Dead? By Tymora's Bosom! Well, they do what they think is right, and that I can respect and understand. That sort of environment is not for me, though. I actually prefer to role-play (it's good enough if you stay in character while you hack and slash) but most of the time I've been in OOC groups as I discover builds' potential in-game.

I'm a fan of moving away from/altering the Vancian system, but this isn't a solution I see as fun.

posts.author: Thell
posts.content:
Thanks for the responses

Yeah, it's a pretty heavy penalty, but thankfully it's an optional path you don't have to take at chargen. Mostly because as JimDandy noted, the admin dislikes Vancian spellcasting.
I am generally puzzled when most of these come out, the ideas behind these RP paths are often very neat but the way they're nerfed makes them inferior to the vanilla classes in almost every way, does make me wonder why they bother sometimes.

Still, better to check than missing a good use for the class. Thanks guys.

posts.author: JimDandy
posts.content: As I understand it, the Prestige Class Consortium has a Psionic class that use a point system for powers. That's my preferred method for any casting, and if I implement PRC in my PW project I would look into how to use the system for existing spell casting classes. It's just how I think magic (arcane, divine, or supernatural (as I classify them)) makes the most sense to be cast. I think it still allows for the current differentiation between wizards and sorcerers having two different main abilities their spell casting power relies on, but I would also change the sorcerer to be more distinct - that's a different topic, however, and something that may be setting/PW specific.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
I'm probably the wrong one to comment on a specific modification to the default ruleset because I don't like many.  There are some servers, like WoG, that has shown some real prudence in monkeying around with the basic mechanics (sometimes I feel as though there are more players that do not really like NWN at all until is morphed into some version of a game that suits their fancy... but it is usually a very small membership that is satisfied for an extended period).

That said, I believe this is just another case of avoiding staleness, incorporating some nuance, however ridiculous, just so the current subscribers remain to see how it can be exploited or attract new players who think "Wow! That's awesome!".  Don't get me wrong.  Running a server is a mind-boggling, tenacious undertaking. And trying to compete for players with all the other servers out there is no picnic.  But at some point, prudence has got to rule the decision-making process.  At least that is my opinion, a dyed-in-the-wool AD&D 3.0 & 3.5 PnPer who has spent more time discussing, debating and implementing even minor changes to suit the community's desires and demands.

My impression of this particular change (I think "tweak" is a w-a-a-a-a-y too rationalized description of a departure from AD&D) is plain silly.  Casters should be the last classes to monkey with... IMO.  A small change can have global implications and this one looks destined to find its manifest destiny along with all the other attempts to "cool off" spellcasting. Don't be surprised if this either goes the way of the dinosaur or an even more inane change follows in its wake. Changes for RP are enough to contend with.  Why muddy the waters even further? 

If they would simply prohibit PvP unless it met a prerequisite party composition (this is a party game, people... never intended to be one-on-one!). then it could be balanced.  We do it all the time in PnP with team PvP.  That's how balancing is achieved and much easier since it leans on the basic mechanics of AD&D.  And, believe it or not, stays interesting when different mixes duel.  *jumping off a tetering soapbox, displaying the obligatory "thumbs down"*

posts.author: furate
posts.content:
What are you talking about, HipMaestro? How does Weave Mastery have anything to do with PvP? Changes on Arelith rarely happen for PvP reasons.

As for Weave Mastery, it is useful, but only when played in a support role. Weave Masters make great support casters, especially given Arelith's resting system.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
furate wrote:
What are you talking about, HipMaestro? How does Weave Mastery have anything to do with PvP? Changes on Arelith rarely happen for PvP reasons.

As for Weave Mastery, it is useful, but only when played in a support role. Weave Masters make great support casters, especially given Arelith's resting system.
It has nothing to do with PvP and I never said it did.

My point was that the so-called "balancing" begins with PvP parity.  Take that factor out of the mix and the default classes need little tinkering if any.  Team play never needs balancing because the teams can use whatever mix of classes they want to balance competition.  

I'm sure Weave Mastery has uses.  All changes do, otherwise why would they spend time implementing it?  Oh right.  I already addressed that. The staleness factor. Most servers have special resting mechanics except the high-magic ones where it doesn't matter anyway.  Whatever floats your boat, mate.  I'm not knocking it. Doesn't matter to me what they do.  It's my opinion based on the years I've played diverse environments and formed my own conclusions about what is AD&D gameplay and what is a vague facsimile designed by others with their own opinions of what makes sense to their audience. Nothing more.
